input: In article <7155@pdxgate.UUCP> idr@rigel.cs.pdx.edu (Ian D Romanick) writes: > One thing:  a small change in initial conditions can cause a huge > change in final conditions.
There are certain things about the way > the plate tektoniks and volcanic activity effect a land scape that > is, while not entirely random, unpredictable.
This is also true with > fractals, so one could also conclude that you could model this > fractally.
Yeah, and it is also true most long complicated sequences of events, calculations, or big computer programs in general.
I do not argue that you can get similar and maybe useful results from fractals, I just question whether you >should<.
The fractal fiends seem to be saying that any part of a system that we can not model should be replaced with a random number generator.

That has been useful, for instance, in making data more palatable to human perception or for torture testing the rest of the system, but I do not think it has much to do with fractals, and I certainly would rather that the model be improved in a more explicable manner.
I guess I just have not seen all these earth-shaking fractal models that explain and correlate to the universe as it actually exists.
I really hope I do, but I am not holding my self-similar breath.
> There is one other thing that fractals are good for:  fractal > image compression.
Uh huh.
I will believe it when I see it.
I have been chasing fractal compression for a few years, and I still do not believe in it.
If it is so great, how come we do not see it competing with JPEG?
Because it can not, I will wager.
Actually, I have wagered, I quit trying to make fractal compression work- and I was trying- because I do not think it is a reasonable alternative to other techniques.
It is neat, though.
:-) I will reiterate my disbelief that everything is fractal.
That is why I do not think fractal compression as it is widely explained is practical.
I know Barnsley and Sloan have some tricks up their sleeves that make their demos work, but I do not see anyone using it in a real product.
It is been six years since Iterated Systems was formed, right?
"There are always going to be questions until there is a product 	out there," Sloan replies.
The company plans to ship its first 	encoding devices in the summer, he says.
In March, Iterated 	Systems will have the other half of the system: the decoders.
- Scientific American, March 1990, page 77 Allen B (Do not even get me started :-) )
